name: Braga
fun_fact: Fun fact: Braga just earned its first Michelin star in February 2025 at Palatial restaurant under chef Rui Filipe - but the real local treasure is bacalhau Ã  Sameiro, a codfish dish so beloved that Braga restaurants have perfected it over generations, each guarding their own secret seasoning recipe.

hero_dishes.name: Bacalhau Ã  Sameiro
hero_dishes.description: Codfish dish with exquisite seasoning and tender texture, capturing the essence of traditional Portuguese cuisine.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after the Sameiro sanctuary near Braga, this codfish preparation represents Minho region's mastery of bacalhau (salted cod). Each restaurant has their own closely guarded recipe, but all emphasize fresh preparation and traditional seasoning.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Arcoense (6km outside city center, renowned for traditional cuisine), Restaurante Cozinha da SÃ© (near cathedral, Michelin-recognized)

hero_dishes.description: Marinated pork cubes fried to perfection with crispy edges and tender centers, accompanied by rice or potatoes.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Minho region classic that showcases Northern Portuguese cooking - simple ingredients transformed through marination and precise frying technique. The dish is hearty, reflecting the agricultural heritage of the region.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Arcoense (specializes in Minho-style rojÃµes with Bisaro pork), Dona JÃºlia (traditional Minho dishes), Restaurante Bem-me-quer

hero_dishes.name: Cabrito Assado (Roast Kid Goat)
hero_dishes.description: Young goat slow-roasted in the oven until tender and falling off the bone, served with roasted potatoes.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Minho specialty that represents Northern Portugal's pastoral heritage. The kid goat is seasoned simply and roasted slowly, allowing the quality of the meat to shine.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Arcoense (Padeiro-style roast kid), Dona JÃºlia (roast kid in the oven, traditional Minho preparation)

hero_dishes.name: Pudim Abade de Priscos
hero_dishes.description: Decadent local dessert pudding with a rich, custardy texture and caramel flavor.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by Abbot Manuel Joaquim Machado Rebelo in the 19th century in nearby Priscos, this pudding became a Braga specialty. The recipe uses port wine and bacon fat, creating a uniquely Portuguese dessert.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants throughout Braga, served as a signature dessert

signature_drinks.name: Vinho Verde
signature_drinks.description: Slightly sparkling 'green wine' from the Minho region, crisp and refreshing with low alcohol.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with seafood and lighter dishes, especially bacalhau. The local production means Braga restaurants offer exceptional selections. Drunk young and cold.

signature_drinks.name: Port Wine
signature_drinks.description: Portugal's famous fortified wine, though produced in Douro Valley, widely enjoyed in Braga.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as an aperitif or digestif at traditional restaurants. Often paired with cheese courses or desserts like Pudim Abade de Priscos.
